snippet: Skype is moving forward on an initial public offering that could be valued at as much as $1 billion, but investors will have to wait until next year before it prices, Reuters reported.
headline: Skype Said to Weigh $1 Billion I.P.O. Next Year

snippet: BankUnited, the Florida lender bought out by a group of high-profile private equity investors last year, is planning to raise as much as $300 million in an initial public offering, the company said Friday.
headline: BankUnited Seeks $300 Million in I.P.O.

snippet: Goldman Sachs is the latest company to issue long-dated debt, taking advantage of low interest rates.
headline: Goldman Sells $1.3 Billion in 50-Year Notes

snippet: Hedge fund and private equity managers, like professional athletes, risk a lot to make a lot. But the big banks pay people millions to gamble with other people’s money.
headline: On Wall Street: All Reward, No Risk

headline: Goodbye Proprietary Trading, Hello Loophole

headline: Wall St. and Private Equity: Frenemies?

snippet: J.C. Flowers & Company, the American private equity firm, is planning bids for four British customer-owned mortgage lenders as part of a plan to create a new “supermutual” that could be partly listed in London, The Observer reported.
headline: J.C. Flowers Is Said to Plan a ‘Supermutual’ Lender

snippet: Wall Street is holding a garage sale, and private equity firms are showing up to buy.
headline: Goldman’s Proprietary Trading Desk to Join K.K.R.

snippet: Goldman Sachs has a $5 billion I.O.U. to Warren Buffett on its books, which the billionaire investor sunk into the bank back in the depths of the financial crisis, now it’s mulling paying it back, The Wall Street Journal reports.
headline: Goldman to Pay Back Buffett’s $5 Billion?

snippet: With stock making up a larger portion of compensation at many firms, investment bankers and traders stand to benefit financially from a longer-term market recovery, says Reuters Breakingviews.

snippet: With stock making up a larger portion of compensation at many firms, investment bankers and traders stand to benefit from a longer-term market recovery.

headline: Goldman in the Pack, Not Leading It

headline: Former Goldman Trader Said to Raise $1 Billion

snippet: Goldman Sachs has been working to repair a public image that has been damaged by accusations that it profited during the financial crisis, but, The New York Post reports, it still may have a way to go — at least according to some investors.
headline: For Goldman, a Problem of Trust?

headline: Musical Chairs: Morgan Eyes Goldman’s Old Building

snippet: Warren Buffett and Henry Kravis are clashing over the debt restructuring of Energy Future Holdings, The New York Post reported.

headline: Standard Chartered to Raise $5.2 Billion

snippet: A Facebook I.P.O. may not be around the corner, but investors may be offered a backdoor — through an initial public offering of Mail.ru Group, the Russian Internet group that’s an investor in the social network.
headline: Russian Facebook Investor to Go Public

headline: Sidney Weinberg Jr., Goldman Banker, Dies at 87

snippet: Mr. Weinberg was a member of the family dynasty that played a central role at Goldman Sachs starting in 1907.
headline: Sidney J. Weinberg Jr., Former Goldman Executive, Dies at 87

snippet: Betfair, the world’s biggest Internet betting exchange, set an indicative price range for its initial public offering that values the company at almost $2.3 billion at the top end.
headline: Betfair I.P.O. Values Company at Up to $2.3 Billion

snippet: Goldman Sachs, which served as the placement agent for a collateralized debt obligation named Davis Square Funding VI, was sued by Landesbank Baden-Wuerttemberg over its $37 million loss on the investment, Bloomberg News reported.
headline: Goldman Sued Over German Bank’s C.D.O. Losses

snippet: Gymboree, the children’s apparel retailer, has hired Goldman Sachs to begin a formal auction of the company, that is expected to fetch more than $1 billion, The New York Post said.
headline: Gymboree Said to Ready Itself for Auction

snippet: The American International Group’s Asian life insurance unit flagged a series of business risks including the collapsed bid from a British rival, Prudential, as it launched its share offering on Tuesday, Reuters said.
headline: A.I.A. Lists Risks as It Launches $15 Billion I.P.O.

snippet: Royal Bank of Scotland may be selling a £3 billion portfolio of property loans, and at least three potential bidders are casting an eye over it, The Sunday Times reported.
headline: Bidders Said to Line Up for R.B.S. Portfolio

snippet: Edwards Group, the private equity-backed vacuum technology firm that is preparing for a sale or flotation, said it “rapidly recovered” from the global downturn and would increase sales and profits further in the second half of the year.
headline: Edwards, Eyeing a Deal, Sees Stronger 2nd Half

snippet: >The New York Time’s Joe Nocera says in his latest column that Anthony Scaramucci, the hedge fund manager who told President Obama that he was whacking Wall Street like a piñata, seems to be in denial. Just like the rest of Wall Street.
headline: Still Stuck in Denial on Wall St.

snippet: Industrial & Commercial Bank of China shares dropped by the most in four months after Goldman Sachs Group sold a stake in the world’s largest lender by market value for 17.45 billion Hong Kong dollars ($2.25 billion), Bloomberg News reported.
headline: I.C.B.C. Stock Takes Hit After Goldman Sells Stake

snippet: The firm’s damaged public image and executive caution have put its junior analysts on alert, reluctant to talk about their jobs to outsiders for fear of judgment.
headline: In Austere Era, Goldman Workers Adopt Lower Profile

snippet: Goldman Sachs has begun a national advertisement campaign aimed at explaining to average citizens what the company does.
headline: Goldman Kicks Off National Advertising Campaign

snippet: Lloyd C. Blankfein, head of Goldman Sachs, told a conference in Brussels that if European regulation became to harsh, the bank would reconsider where it based certain operations, The Financial Times reported.

snippet: GNC, the privately-backed retail vitamin company, is planning to raise $350 million in an initial public offering.
headline: GNC Plans $350 Million I.P.O.

snippet: Avenue Capital Group, the hedge fund-firm run by Marc Lasry, is in talks to hire members of Goldman Sach’s proprietary-trading business in the U.S., Bloomberg News reported.
headline: Avenue Capital in Talks With Goldman’s Prop Traders?

snippet: Writers of the new financial regulations have barely started, and the extent of their task is still uncertain. But some winners and losers seem evident already.
headline: The Regulatory Pregame: Laying Bets on the Winners

snippet: In the election for state comptroller, incumbent Thomas P. DiNapoli is betting his challenger’s hedge fund career will make him look untrustworthy, but some analysts wonder if that will resonate with voters in New York.
headline: In State Comptroller Race, It’s Albany v. Wall Street

snippet: Endesa, a Spanish utility controlled by Enel of Italy, agreed to sell 80 percent of its natural gas distribution assets to two Goldman Sachs infrastructure funds.
headline: Goldman Funds Buy Endesa Assets

snippet: NBC Universal on Monday launched a $5.1 billion, four-part debt sale, said IFR, a Thomson Reuters service.
headline: NBC Launches $5.1 Billion Debt Sale

snippet: Credit Suisse lowers earnings estimates for Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley but praises Goldman’s “expense discipline.”
headline: A Leaner Goldman Sachs Is Seen

snippet: The company’s current examination of its business practices offers a good opportunity for separating the roles of the chief executive and the chairman.
headline: Room at the Top at Goldman Sachs

snippet: The firm’s chief executive, Lloyd Blankfein; its president, Gary Cohn; and other top executives are set to receive $111 million in deferred compensation, Bloomberg News reports.
headline: Goldman Sachs’ $111 Million Bonus Windfall

snippet: Sergey Aleynikov, a former programmer accused of stealing computer code when he left the firm, awaits the verdict.
headline: Jury Debates Goldman Sachs Code Case

snippet: Goldman Sachs’ Petershill Fund has agreed to buy a minority stake in Mount Lucas, a Pennsylvania-based firm, as industry deal-making remains strong.

snippet: Bonus agreements can be torn up if the government ever needs to bail out the bank.
headline: Goldman Adopts ‘Brake’ Provision on Bonuses

snippet: In this CNBC interview, the Goldman Sachs Asset Management chairman explains why he is increasingly optimistic about the outlook for 2011.
headline: Jim O’Neill, Goldman’s Vocal Bull

snippet: The Treasury Department released its November agenda for meetings related to the influential Dodd-Frank financial overhaul law — a list that reads like a who’s who of finance.
headline: Wall Street Visits Washington About Dodd-Frank

snippet: American companies could save more than $1 billion a year if banks charged the same fees for initial public offerings as in Europe, according to a study by three British academics.
headline: High I.P.O. Fees Weigh on U.S. Firms, Study Finds

snippet: Henry Paulson, the former U.S. Treasury secretary sold his Washington, D.C., home at a $1 million loss last week.
headline: The Latest Victim of the Housing Slump: Henry Paulson

snippet: Morgan Chia-Wen Sze is said to be seeking to raise $1.5 billion for a hedge fund based in Hong Kong.
headline: Goldman Trader Set to Create Fund

snippet: Goldman Sachs is sticking to its growth strategy of being “Goldman in more places,’’ Glenn Schorr says.
headline: Blankfein Sees Investment Banking Revival, Analyst Says

snippet: Despite worries about a credit crisis, the founder of the hedge fund firm Odey Asset Management likes European stocks, particularly those in Germany.
headline: Odey Optimistic About Europe

snippet: With the end of the year upon us, White Collar Watch looks at some of the trends in criminal and civil cases that will continue in 2011.
headline: A Preview of the Trials and Tribulations in 2011

snippet:
Lloyd Blankfein, C.E.O. and chairman of Goldman Sachs, is one of the few bank chiefs to hold both posts.
DealBook talks to Rob Cox, U.S. Editor for Reuters Breakingviews, about dividing the roles.
headline: Viewpoints: Splitting Blankfein's Roles

headline: Morning Take-Out

snippet: Despite increasing regulatory pressure and weaker trading profits, banks increased the amount of derivatives on their books by $11.3 trillion in the third quarter, according to the O.C.C.
headline: Banks Increase Derivatives Holdings

snippet: Traders, bankers and brokers face a bonus of nothing, and if their salaries have doubled, that is little consolation.
headline: This Bonus Season on Wall Street, Many See Zeros

snippet: Glenn Schorr, a Nomura analyst, said overall pay at Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase and other investment banks may remain high even as overall revenue has declined.
headline: For Wall Street Banks, Little ‘Flexibility’ on Pay

snippet: John Paulson, Nelson Peltz and Daniel S. Och were among the 1,100 members of New York’s Jewish community at the group’s annual Wall Street gathering on Wednesday.
headline: Finance A-Listers Come Out for UJA-Federation Dinner

snippet: The billionaire businessman Kenneth G. Langone discusses the Madoff scandal, President Obama’s health care program and insider trading with the hosts of CNBC’s “The Strategy Session.”
headline: Ken Langone Uncensored

snippet: Bloomberg, ICE, TradeWeb and others want approval to become derivatives trading platforms, which are emerging as a central component of the Dodd-Frank overhaul.
headline: Swap Execution Facility: The New Term on Wall Street

snippet: Phillip Hylander, the head of the firm’s principal strategic investments group, is retiring and will become an advisory director.
headline: Goldman Revamps London Equities Team

snippet: The government’s case against Sergey Aleynikov, a former Goldman Sachs programmer, highlighted the importance of proprietary computer codes in the profitable high-frequency trading by Wall Street firms.
headline: Former Goldman Programmer Found Guilty of Code Theft

snippet: The founder of the private equity behemoth talked about the industry’s improving outlook and how consumers can help his companies this holiday season.
headline: K.K.R.’s Kravis on Why He’s Optimistic

headline: Goldman’s Cohn May Be Interviewed in Gupta Case

snippet: The crop of 261 executives is the smallest at Goldman in years, reflecting a recent cost-cutting push by the firm.

snippet: As the ax continues to fall on Wall Street, Citigroup is drawing up plans to eliminate about 3,000 jobs, while BNP Paribas intends to cut about 1,400 positions.
headline: Citi to Shed 3,000 Jobs; BNP Paribas Plans to Cut About 1,400

headline: Nuns Who Won’t Stop Nudging

headline: High Ideals and Corruption Dominate Think Festival Agenda

headline: For Goldman, Trading Losses on 21 Days in Third Quarter

headline: Yelp Hires Goldman and Citigroup to Lead I.P.O.

headline: One Bank Dominates Headlines (Take a Wild Guess)

snippet: The fund, the firm’s fifth, will make investments of $14 million to $69 million in European and American technology start-ups.
headline: Index Ventures Raises $700 Million Growth Fund

headline: Goldman Sachs Reports $428 Million Loss

headline: Did You Hear the One About the Bankers?

headline: Romney Ahead in Race for Wall Street Cash

headline: The Missed Red Flags on Groupon

headline: Goldman Sachs Draws Up Deeper Cuts

headline: As Calls for Protests Go Global, Italy Jumps the Gun

snippet: The top financial regulator in Massachusetts is concerned about the staffing services provided to hedge funds by big Wall Street banks.
headline: Massachusetts Asks Banks for Details on Recruiting

snippet: The investment in ZocDoc, an online service that helps consumers book and manage doctor appointments. is the latest start-up bet by the Wall Street firm.
headline: Goldman Sachs Invests $25 Million in ZocDoc

headline: Amid Protests, Blankfein Cancels College Talk

snippet: Economic turmoil worldwide and at home threatens the profits and bonuses at the big banks, the New York comptroller said.
headline: New York May Lose 10,000 Wall St. Jobs, Report Says

snippet: In an effort to secure lucrative brokerage and trading business, big banks like Goldman Sachs, Deutsche Bank, Morgan Stanley and Bank of America have become powerful recruiting forces for their biggest hedge fund clients.
headline: Wall St. Banks Help Hedge Funds Recruit

headline: Details Emerge on Draft of Volcker Rule

snippet: The closure marks a sharp reversal for Global Alpha, one of Goldman Sachs’s best-known hedge funds, after it rung up big losses this year.
headline: Goldman Sachs to Shut Its Global Alpha Hedge Fund

snippet: The Clearing House Association warns that requiring layers of bank capital protection would devastate the industry’s returns and have a chilling effect on the economy.
headline: Clearing House Group Assails Bank Capital Rules

headline: H.P. Hires Goldman to Defend Against Activists

snippet: American investment banks have been competitive in international offerings, but have not competed at all for Chinese companies raising money domestically.
headline: Chinese Policies Put Squeeze On the Banks

snippet: With growth flat at home, companies turn their eyes to remote regions of the world like Sri Lanka, Zimbabwe and Uruguay.
headline: Untapped and Growing, Frontier Markets Beckon

headline: A Trader’s Truth, or a Prank?

headline: Milestone Moment for S.E.C. in Insider Case

headline: Goldman Names New Head of Europe and Asia Pacific Mergers

snippet: An ongoing conversation with business owners who meet regularly to share their successes and struggles.
headline: Going Behind the Scenes With Four Owners

snippet: The $2 billion trading loss that has rocked the Swiss banking giant UBS has also cast a spotlight on a relatively unknown but increasingly profitable corner of Wall Street  — Delta One desks.

headline: Regulators Aim to End ‘Too Big To Fail’

snippet: McGraw-Hill will spin off its educational unit and concentrate on its business information services in an effort to raise its flat share price.
headline: To Lift Stock, McGraw-Hill Will Split in Two

snippet: A new Twitter account claims to dish the dirt on what gets overheard inside the elevators at the Wall Street firm.
headline: Meet the Goldman Sachs Banker Behind @GSElevator

headline: The Last Women Standing on Wall Street

snippet: The suit accuses 11 firms, including Blackstone Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, of a conspiracy to rig the market for multibillion-dollar takeovers.
headline: Judge Widens Antitrust Suit Against Private Equity Firms

headline: Dunkin’ Donuts Parent Gets Mixed Reviews

headline: U.S. Takes Hard Line in Suits Over Bad Mortgages

snippet: In an attempt to appease Citadel, the online brokerage company announced on Monday that it has created a new special committee to evaluate the company’s strategic options and has hired Goldman Sachs to advise.
headline: Bowing to Citadel, E*Trade Hires Goldman Sachs

headline: Bank Suits Over Mortgages Are Filed

headline: The Friendly New Face of Goldman

headline: Federal Regulators Sue Big Banks Over Mortgages

headline: Blankfein’s Tenure at Goldman Sachs

snippet: As Hurricane Irene travels up the East Coast, New York is steeling itself for disaster, with several big financial firms located in designated flood zones.

snippet: Bloomberg L.P.’s purchase of the Bureau of National Affairs for about $1 billion cash reflects Bloomberg’s ardor to expand its influence and build a cushion against Wall Street.
headline: A Big Purchase for Bloomberg

snippet: While he is investing $5 billion into Bank of America, Warren E. Buffett is no stranger to taking up positions in the nation’s biggest lenders.

snippet: Jonathan Sorrell, a top banker at Goldman Sachs, will join the Man Group as head of strategy for the European hedge fund giant.

headline: Goldman and Citigroup Hire Moody’s to Salvage Bond Sale

headline: Goldman Sachs Disappoints With Earnings of $1.05 Billion

snippet: The company, a social network tool for businesses, is the latest into the pipeline of technology I.P.O.’s.
headline: Jive Software Files to Go Public

snippet: On Thursday, Berkshire Hathaway, run by Warren E. Buffett, announced plans to invest $5 billion in Bank of America, a vote of confidence for the beleaguered financial firm.

snippet: Breaking the so-called golden handcuffs of finance can be tough, but several Goldman Sachs have successfully left the fold to pursue their passions.
headline: Riffing on Life After Goldman Sachs

snippet: To back up its bid for Kinetic Concepts, which would top a $4.9 billion deal with Apax Partners, Convatec has obtained “highly confident” financing letters from its investment banks.

snippet: The Wall Street plans to lay off 230 employees in New York. The job cuts would begin at the end of September.

snippet: DealBook presents the full list of advisers on Hewlett-Packard’s $11.7 billion takeover of Autonomy, which represents a small army of bankers and lawyers.

snippet: No one disputes that Goldman Sachs shorted the housing market. The problem is not the size or the timing of the short selling, it’s how the investment bank went about doing so.

snippet: Economic turmoil worldwide and at home threatens the profits and bonuses at the big banks, the New York comptroller said.
headline: New York May Lose 10,000 Wall St. Jobs, Report Says

snippet: In an effort to secure lucrative brokerage and trading business, big banks like Goldman Sachs, Deutsche Bank, Morgan Stanley and Bank of America have become powerful recruiting forces for their biggest hedge fund clients.
headline: Wall St. Banks Help Hedge Funds Recruit

snippet: The draft document from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation expands the ban on proprietary trading by banks, but it leaves many details to be determined.
headline: Details Emerge on Draft of Volcker Rule

snippet: The closure marks a sharp reversal for Global Alpha, one of Goldman Sachs’s best-known hedge funds, after it rung up big losses this year.
headline: Goldman Sachs to Shut Its Global Alpha Hedge Fund

snippet: The Clearing House Association warns that requiring layers of bank capital protection would devastate the industry’s returns and have a chilling effect on the economy.
headline: Clearing House Group Assails Bank Capital Rules

snippet: Hewlett-Packard has hired Goldman Sachs to defend against possible attacks by activist investors or unwanted suitors, as the technology giant struggles to turn itself around.
headline: H.P. Hires Goldman to Defend Against Activists

snippet: Banks like Citigroup, Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley are chasing the potential payoff abroad. But there’s a quiet truth to success in those risky markets: the path to profits is often filled with mistakes and setbacks.
headline: Emerging Markets Offer Banks Profits, but Headaches Too

snippet: American investment banks have been competitive in international offerings, but have not competed at all for Chinese companies raising money domestically.
headline: Chinese Policies Put Squeeze On the Banks

snippet: With growth flat at home, companies turn their eyes to remote regions of the world like Sri Lanka, Zimbabwe and Uruguay.
headline: Untapped and Growing, Frontier Markets Beckon

snippet: The video seemed almost too good to be true: an independent stock trader’s unvarnished opinion of how the world works that confirmed many stereotypes about Wall Street.
headline: A Trader’s Truth, or a Prank?

snippet: As Wall Street moves to shed jobs by the thousands, Capital One, whose planned acquisition of ING Direct USA has drawn scrutiny, trumpeted its plans to hire more than 3,600 new employees in 2011.
headline: Capital One Says ING Direct Deal Will Create Jobs

snippet: White Collar Watch examines the Securities and Exchange Commission’s first insider trading case involving an exchange-traded fund.
headline: Milestone Moment for S.E.C. in Insider Case

snippet: A former Goldman Sachs banker, Jim Himes understands the world of high finance better than most of his Congressional peers, and that is less of an asset than it once was.
headline: Wall Street Ties Bring Peril for Democratic Lawmaker

snippet: Goldman Sachs’s parts — an industry-leading investment bank, an extensive securities trading operation and an asset management arm — may be worth a lot more than the whole.
headline: Breaking Up Could Be Good for Goldman Sachs

snippet: Goldman Sachs has named Gregg Lemkau as its head of mergers and acquisitions for Europe, the Middle East, Africa and Asia Pacific countries.
headline: Goldman Names New Head of Europe and Asia Pacific Mergers

snippet: The S.E.C. said the former Goldman Sachs employee once tipped his father to a crucial shakeup in the firm’s exchange-traded funds division.
headline: S.E.C. Accuses Ex-Goldman Employee of Insider Trading

snippet: Katinka Domotorffy, the head of the quantitative investment strategies group, will retire from Goldman Sachs at the end of the year, according to a letter sent to investors.
headline: Head of Goldman’s Computer-Trading Shop to Step Down

snippet: An ongoing conversation with business owners who meet regularly to share their successes and struggles.
headline: Going Behind the Scenes With Four Owners

headline: Regulators Aim to End ‘Too Big To Fail’

headline: Meet the Goldman Sachs Banker Behind @GSElevator

snippet: The suit accuses 11 firms, including Blackstone Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, of a conspiracy to rig the market for multibillion-dollar takeovers.
headline: Judge Widens Antitrust Suit Against Private Equity Firms

headline: Dunkin’ Donuts Parent Gets Mixed Reviews

headline: U.S. Takes Hard Line in Suits Over Bad Mortgages

headline: Bowing to Citadel, E*Trade Hires Goldman Sachs

headline: The Friendly New Face of Goldman

headline: Federal Regulators Sue Big Banks Over Mortgages

headline: Blankfein’s Tenure at Goldman Sachs

headline: As Irene Approaches, Banks Prepare for the Worst

headline: A Big Purchase for Bloomberg

snippet: While he is investing $5 billion into Bank of America, Warren E. Buffett is no stranger to taking up positions in the nation’s biggest lenders.
headline: Buffett Adds Another Bank to His Portfolio

snippet: Jonathan Sorrell, a top banker at Goldman Sachs, will join the Man Group as head of strategy for the European hedge fund giant.
headline: Top Goldman Banker to Join Man Group

headline: Goldman and Citigroup Hire Moody’s to Salvage Bond Sale

headline: Goldman Sachs Disappoints With Earnings of $1.05 Billion

headline: Goldman’s Shares Tumble as Blankfein Hires Top Lawyer

snippet: The company, a social network tool for businesses, is the latest into the pipeline of technology I.P.O.’s.
headline: Jive Software Files to Go Public

headline: Buffett Invests $5 Billion in Bank of America

headline: Riffing on Life After Goldman Sachs

snippet: To back up its bid for Kinetic Concepts, which would top a $4.9 billion deal with Apax Partners, Convatec has obtained “highly confident” financing letters from its investment banks.
headline: ConvaTec Said to Bid for Kinetic Concepts

snippet: The Wall Street plans to lay off 230 employees in New York. The job cuts would begin at the end of September.
headline: Goldman Sachs Prepares to Cut Jobs

snippet: DealBook presents the full list of advisers on Hewlett-Packard’s $11.7 billion takeover of Autonomy, which represents a small army of bankers and lawyers.
headline: The Advisers Behind H.P.’s Autonomy Deal

snippet: No one disputes that Goldman Sachs shorted the housing market. The problem is not the size or the timing of the short selling, it’s how the investment bank went about doing so.
headline: Misdirection in Goldman Sachs’s Housing Short

snippet: When Goldman went public in 1999, a group of 221 executives controlled the firm. Now, only 39 remain, with the others going to top jobs in finance, government and even sports.
headline: The Goldman Sachs Diaspora

snippet: The National Credit Union Administration says Goldman Sachs misrepresented securities in offering documents as safer than they were.
headline: Credit Union Regulator Accuses Goldman

snippet: Goldman lost money on 15 days in the second quarter, one of the worst trading performances the bank has posted in some time.
headline: Goldman Gives Details on Lackluster Quarter

snippet: Wall Street executives and some market insiders feel the sell-off in bank stocks has been overdone. But some big institutions have been selling for months.
headline: The Trouble With Financial Stocks

snippet: Occupy Wall Street protesters picket Goldman Sachs.
headline: TimesCast | Protests at Goldman Sachs

snippet: The appointment of  Pete Lyon comes a day after Goldman Sachs announced the retirement of Milton R. Berlinski, a 26-year Goldman veteran who had run the unit alongside Alison Mass.
headline: Goldman Sachs Names Co-Head of Private Equity Banking Group

snippet: Breakingviews envisions some of the possibilities in a hypothetical memo to shareholders that wouldn’t be surprising to see from Goldman during 2012.
headline: A Future Memo From Goldman

snippet: There is no disputing that developing more jobs in different fields would be better for New York, and the country, than fighting financial regulations.
headline: Wall Street Meets Reality

snippet: Goldman Sachs, Vodafone and other big businesses were treated too favorably by British tax officials, potentially costing the nation billions of pounds of revenue as a result, according to a government report released on Tuesday.
headline: British Tax Office Assailed for ‘Cozy’ Ties With Big Companies

snippet: While shares of the online game company continued to fall on Monday, Zynga’s underwriters, including Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs, shared $32.5 million for handling the I.P.O.
headline: Even as Zynga Slides, Bankers Reap Big Fees

snippet: Seven investment banks will be giving up their claim to some $150 million in advisory fees. And some firms’ rankings will be affected in the year-end league tables as a result.
headline: AT&T Deal’s Wall Street Losers

snippet: Milton Berlinski,  who runs the group at Goldman Sachs that caters to private equity firms, is leaving.
headline: A Top Goldman Executive to Retire

snippet: More than a dozen Goldman partners have announced plans to leave recently, a much higher number than in years past, including some well-known names on Wall Street like Kevin Kennedy and Jeff Resnick.
headline: A Wave of Partner Retirements at Goldman Sachs

snippet: Philip A. Falcone, the founder of Harbinger Capital Partners, received a Wells Notice from the S.E.C., which usually means the commission is planning enforcement proceedings.
headline: S.E.C. Looks at Harbinger’s Dealings With Goldman

snippet: University recruiting sessions by JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs were disrupted this week by stealth protesters from the Occupy Princeton movement.
headline: An Orange and Black Eye for 2 Banks

snippet: In one banker’s view, developments in the world’s fast-growth markets will prove much more important to investors than the issues of the euro zone.
headline: Looking Beyond Europe

snippet: Edward C. Forst, the co-head of asset management, is retiring from Goldman Sachs amid questions about his leadership style.
headline: High-Level Goldman Executive Is Leaving the Firm

snippet: Nexon, a fast-growing Asian online game company, set the price for its initial public offering at $16.68 a share, a debut that could value the company at $7.2 billion.
headline: Zynga Rival in Japan Prices $1.2 Billion I.P.O.

snippet: Michael Kors, the fashion apparel and accessories maker, announced plans on Friday to go public, an offering that could value the company at $3.63 billion.
headline: Michael Kors Readies to Go Public

snippet: Using a new standard announced recently, Standard and Poor’s reduced the credit rating for seven of the top eight American banks, as well as banks in Europe.
headline: S.&P. Cuts Its Ratings for 15 Banks

snippet: The antibank fervor of the Occupy Wall Street movement has entered college campuses, complicating the on-campus recruiting process for applicants and recruiters.
headline: At Top Colleges, Anti-Wall St. Fervor Complicates Recruiting

snippet: As he did with Bank of America, Judge Jed S. Rakoff wants Citigroup to take more responsibility for the “truth” of its wrongdoing in its settlement with the S.E.C.
headline: Behind Rakoff’s Rejection of Citigroup Settlement

snippet: The police said the protesters apparently held a mock trial of Goldman Sachs, a main target of the Occupy Wall Street movement, at their encampment in Zuccotti Park before setting out for the building to deliver their verdict.
headline: Protesters Arrested Outside Goldman Sachs Building

snippet: Gary D. Cohn’s name emerged during a court hearing as prosecutors and lawyers for Rajat K. Gupta, a former Goldman Sachs director, debated the timing of depositions that are set to be taken in a parallel S.E.C. case against Mr. Gupta.
headline: Goldman’s Cohn May Be Interviewed in Gupta Case

snippet: The crop of 261 executives is the smallest at Goldman in years, reflecting a recent cost-cutting push by the firm.
headline: Goldman Names Managing Directors

snippet: The “beige book,” a quarterly report produced by Goldman Sachs that emphasizes pithy statements by executives in earnings conference calls, makes for disturbing reading about the economy.
headline: From the Mouths of Executives, Little Comfort

snippet: As the ax continues to fall on Wall Street, Citigroup is drawing up plans to eliminate about 3,000 jobs, while BNP Paribas intends to cut about 1,400 positions.
headline: Citi to Shed 3,000 Jobs; BNP Paribas Plans to Cut About 1,400

snippet: Long before Occupy Wall Street, the Sisters of St. Francis were quietly staging an occupation of their own, and have become one of the most surprising groups of corporate activists.
headline: Nuns Who Won’t Stop Nudging

snippet: The Goa Think Festival, a battleground of ideas and ideologies, but not too far from controversy.
headline: High Ideals and Corruption Dominate Think Festival Agenda

snippet: A new regulatory filing details how weak the third quarter — when the firm reported its first quarterly loss since the financial crisis — really was.
headline: For Goldman, Trading Losses on 21 Days in Third Quarter

snippet: Yelp, the online reviews site for local businesses, has turned to Goldman Sachs and Citigroup to lead its initial public offering, according to people briefed on the situation.
headline: Yelp Hires Goldman and Citigroup to Lead I.P.O.

snippet: A single investment bank received 15.9 percent of all Wall Street media mentions in the first 10 months of 2011, according to a new study. Can you guess which?
headline: One Bank Dominates Headlines (Take a Wild Guess)

snippet: The fund, the firm’s fifth, will make investments of $14 million to $69 million in European and American technology start-ups.
headline: Index Ventures Raises $700 Million Growth Fund

snippet: The sluggish economy and Dodd-Frank restrictions are affecting bankers’ compensation, leading to the weakest bonus season since the financial crisis.
headline: Wall St. Pay Expected to Fall 20% to 30%

snippet: Goldman Sachs, weighed down by problems in its private equity portfolio and the broader global economic woes, reported a loss of $428 million.
headline: Goldman Sachs Reports $428 Million Loss

snippet: Robert Woo, who was paralyzed after an accident in 2007, took his first steps Thursday using a bionic device that gives hope to paraplegics that they may one day walk on their own.
headline: Walking Again, With Help From an Exoskeleton

snippet: A series of blunders by former senior executives of Goldman Sachs raises questions about whether the firm’s secret for success can actually be exported.
headline: It’s Lonely Without the Goldman Net

snippet: M. Michele Burns, the former chief executive of the human resource consulting firm Mercer, has been elected to Goldman’s board.

snippet: While the world watched the demise of Qaddafi, some unsettling news from Wall Street helped explain why all those protests are resonating.
headline: Did You Hear the One About the Bankers?

snippet: No one disputes that Goldman Sachs shorted the housing market. The problem is not the size or the timing of the short selling, it’s how the investment bank went about doing so.

snippet: Colm Kelleher, who was named the sole head of Morgan Stanley’s securities arm on Monday, faces some significant challenges in transforming the bank’s fixed-income division.
headline: Morgan Stanley’s Fix-It Job in Fixed Income

snippet: Financial firms have promised various forms of aid, including donations, loans and waived fees, and many in the financial industry are volunteering in recovery efforts.
headline: Wall Street Turns to Hurricane Relief

snippet: Year-end incentives will be flat to up to 10 percent higher when compared with last year, a survey is forecasting, but the increase is from one of the worst years for bank pay in recent memory.
headline: Bonuses on Wall St. Expected to Edge Up

snippet: The shops and restaurants surrounding Goldman Sachs’s 200 West Street headquarters were doing brisk business on Friday, even as the streets beyond lay dormant.
headline: Around Goldman’s Headquarters, an Oasis of Electricity

snippet: Many of the investment products that helped lead to the financial crisis contained ample disclosures of their risks, but the sophisticated investors who lost billions failed to heed warning signs that should have led them to further investigation.
headline: Reading the Fine Print in Abacus and Other Soured Deals

snippet: Social media sites were buzzing with photographs and other updates about the approaching storm and its impact on Manhattan’s financial industry and the markets.
headline: Hurricane Preparations on Wall Street, the Social Media Edition

snippet: Employees at many financial firms are being asked to work from home on Monday as Hurricane Sandy bears down on the East Coast, with Citigroup, Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase planning to close their offices in Manhattan.
headline: Wall Street Prepares to Work From Home as Storm Approaches

snippet: In India, students are spooked, anti-corruption activists wary and scholars intrigued.
headline: India Reacts to Gupta’s Sentence

snippet: Restoration Hardware said in a filing on Tuesday that it planned to sell 5.2 million shares at $22 to $24 a share in an initial public offering.
headline: Restoration Hardware Sets Price Range for I.P.O.

snippet: The book “Why I Left Goldman Sachs” by Greg Smith, a former Goldman employee, is about how the firm’s culture broke down. Yet it is oddly also a testament to some of the ways in which the Wall Street firm’s culture still works.
headline: Is Greg Smith Believable?

snippet: Standard & Poor’s has released an analysis on Monday contending that Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley, more than any other Wall Street bank, could suffer under the so-called Volcker Rule.
headline: Standard & Poor’s Warns of Possible Volcker Rule Downgrades

snippet: Shares of Goldman Sachs rose as much as 4 percent in trading on Monday morning, as investors considered a bullish argument for the firm that appeared in Barron’s this weekend.
headline: The Bullish Case for Goldman Sachs

snippet: When Goldman Sachs bought the commodities broker J. Aron & Company in 1981, the cultures clashed, but now J. Aron alumni control the elevator to the executive suite.
headline: The J. Aron Takeover of Goldman Sachs

snippet: After a former executive, Greg Smith, resigned from Goldman Sachs in a letter to The New York Times, he fails to deliver much more in his book on the firm.
headline: A Tell-All on Goldman Has Little Worth Telling

snippet: Greg Smith’s reminiscences of the pleasures of the job but does not seem to break much new ground on questionable practices at Goldman Sachs.
headline: Greg Smith’s Memoir Offers Few New Details on Goldman

headline: In Goldman Case, Re-examining Foreign Sales

snippet: Newsweek announced it would cease print publication at the end of the year and move to an all-digital format, and a former Goldman Sachs trader offers few details in his new tell-all.
headline: Breakfast Meeting: Bowing to Pressure, Newsweek Will End Print Edition

snippet: It will not be surprising if Judge Jed S. Rakoff starts out at a much lower recommended sentence than what the government wants for Rajat K. Gupta, the former Goldman Sachs director who was convicted on charges of insider trading and conspiracy.
headline: Weighing the Factors in the Gupta Sentencing

snippet: While it may be tempting to ignore value at risk altogether because it has proved of little worth when times get tough, that might be mistake. Value-at risk-measurements play a crucial role in setting capital.
headline: When Wall Street Firms Change Risk Models

snippet: Rajat K. Gupta, who has been convicted of insider trading, has asked a judge for a lenient sentence that would send him to Rwanda to perform humanitarian work rather than spending 8 to 10 years in prison.
headline: Push for Leniency as an Ex-Goldman Director Faces Sentencing

snippet: Helped by its powerful trading business, the firm’s revenue more than doubled in the third quarter, to $8.35 billion, exceeding the estimates of Wall Street analysts.
headline: Private Equity Gains Helped Lift Revenue in Goldman’s 3rd Quarter

snippet: In the first chapter of his book “Why I Left Goldman Sachs, A Wall Street Story,” Greg Smith, a former salesman for the Wall Street firm, writes of interns who had to carry a stool with them.
headline: Book by Disgruntled Ex-Salesman Offers His Analysis of the Culture at Goldman

snippet: Adebayo O. Ogunlesi is well-known on Wall Street, having run the investment bank at Credit Suisse in the last decade. Since 2006, he has run Global Infrastructure Partners, a private equity firm that invests in infrastructure deals like energy pro...
headline: Goldman Names Ogunlesi to Board

snippet: The Yankees are looking for the right investor to buy out their partners in the YES Network, including Goldman Sachs.
headline: Yankees Seeking Changes in YES Ownership

snippet: For the small battalion of bankers and lawyers advising EADS and BAE Systems, the end of merger talks between the two aerospace giants brings no small amount of anguish over lost fees.
headline: Collapse of Aerospace Merger Deals Blow to Army of Advisers

snippet: Goldman Sachs has made an effort to heal self-inflicted wounds and maintain its dominance in investment banking.
headline: Behind Goldman Sachs’s Success Is a Focus on Survival

snippet: There is a significant loophole in the double jeopardy clause — known as the “dual sovereignty” doctrine — that permits different governments to pursue the same case.
headline: In Goldman Programmer Case, a Way Around Double Jeopardy

snippet: More than three years after appearing in Federal District Court in Manhattan on corporate theft charges, the former programmer, Sergey Aleynikov, was in a New York State court to plead not guilty to similar charges.
headline: Lawyer for Ex-Goldman Programmer Criticizes Prosecutors and Firm

snippet: Goldman Sachs settled allegations on Thursday that one of its investment bankers curried favor with a public official to win lucrative government contracts in Massachusetts.
headline: Goldman to Pay $12 Million to Settle S.E.C. ‘Pay to Play’ Case

snippet: Coming less than a year after an explosive opinion article, Greg Smith’s memoir, “Why I Left Goldman Sachs,” promises to be a tell-all of his 12-year career at the Wall Street bank.
headline: Former Banker Promises Inside Peek at Goldman

snippet: The Carlyle Group said Friday that it had bought Cogentrix Energy’s North American power plants from Goldman Sachs, as the private equity firm seeks to build up a presence in the energy business.
headline: Carlyle Buys Power Plants From Goldman Sachs

snippet: A former Goldman Sachs programmer who faces new charges of stealing computer code is demanding that the investment bank cover his mounting legal fees.
headline: Former Programmer Demands That Goldman Cover His Legal Fees

snippet: In the third quarter of 2012, mergers and acquisition activity was $455 billion worldwide. The U.S. share was $195 billion. Goldman Sachs and Freshfields Bruckhaus Deringer were the top financial and legal advisers.
headline: Graphic: Mergers and Acquisitions, Top Financial and Legal Advisers

snippet: Goldman Sachs said Tuesday that David A. Viniar, the bank’s longtime chief financial officer, would retire at the end of January and be replaced by Harvey Schwartz, a senior executive at the bank.
headline: Executive at Goldman Is Retiring

snippet: Trulia, the real estate information site, rose 30 percent in its debut to open at roughly $22, defying the recent lackluster performance of newly public stocks.
headline: Trulia Jumps 40% in Debut

snippet: The private equity firm said on Monday that it had named Robert Mancini — the chief executive of the power company Cogentrix and a managing director at Goldman Sachs — as the co-head of its $1.14 billion infrastructure fund.
headline: Carlyle Hires Goldman Executive as Co-Head of Its Infrastructure Fund

snippet: Abercrombie & Fitch has retained Goldman Sachs as an adviser as the troubled clothier assesses potential responses to moves by one of its investors, the activist hedge fund Relational Investors, a person briefed on the matter said on Wednesday.
headline: Abercrombie Hires Goldman

snippet: Adrianne Shapira, a retail industry analyst at Goldman Sachs, is headed to the jewelry company David Yurman to be its chief financial officer.
headline: Goldman Analyst Headed to David Yurman

snippet: According to people familiar with his plans, J. Michael Evans, a Goldman Sachs vice chairman, will list his Upper West Side condominium for $26 million. He has also put up for sale another apartment that he owns in the building and has recently pu...
headline: For a Goldman Executive, More Real Estate Dealings

snippet: Heavily redacted documents showed top private equity firms agreeing among themselves on which would bid on takeover targets.
headline: Equity Firms Like Bain Are Depicted as Colluding

snippet: Stephen J. McGuinness, the former co-chief operating officer of Goldman Sachs Asset Management, has joined the investment firm Strategic Value Partners as a senior managing director.
headline: Former Goldman Executive Joins Strategic Value Partners

snippet: In a survey of some 3,500 Wall Street professionals, JPMorgan’s investment bank was selected as the best firm to work for in North America this year, judging by quality of life and overall prestige.
headline: Survey Deems JPMorgan’s Investment Bank Best Place to Work

snippet: Federal authorities ended two separate investigations into mortgage-related investments during the financial crisis, handing a quiet victory to the bank after years of public scrutiny.
headline: S.E.C. and Justice Dept. End Mortgage Investigations Into Goldman

snippet: Discolored tap water afflicted Goldman’s gleaming new headquarters in lower Manhattan earlier this month.
headline: At Goldman Sachs, Something in the Water

snippet: J. Michael Evans, a Goldman Sachs vice chairman and a leading candidate to become the bank’s next chief, is said to have bought an entire floor at 995 Fifth Avenue for $27 million.
headline: Goldman Executive Is Said to Buy $27 Million Luxury Apartment

snippet: On the day it paid $20.7 million to Bayou hedge fund investors, Goldman Sachs filed to get the same amount back from Bayou as a creditor.
headline: Goldman, Still Playing in Bayou’s Mud

snippet: A decision by Judge Paul A. Crotty of Federal District Court in Manhattan will put the firm’s 2007 sales of collateralized debt obligations tied to subprime mortgages back under the microscope.
headline: The Litigation That Haunts Goldman Sachs

snippet: What does a financial giant owe to its clients? That question is at the heart of the battle between the founders of Dragon Systems and Goldman Sachs, their banker, in a sale that went horribly awry.
headline: Goldman Sachs and the $580 Million Black Hole

snippet: Though the jury is out on how companies like Facebook and Groupon will ultimately fare and whether the investments of 2011 will turn to busts, Wall Street’s biggest investors still have plenty of skin in the game.
headline: Shine Is Off Wall Street’s Big Bet on Internet Start-Ups

snippet: After deciding not to prosecute Goldman Sachs for its conduct during the financial crisis, the Justice Department did something rare: it publicly announced that the investigation was closed.
headline: U.S. Goldman Disclosure a Rare Break in Secrecy

snippet: The disclosures that the Justice Department has closed an investigation of Goldman Sachs and that the Securities and Exchange Commission has decided not to pursue a civil fraud case may turn out to be the denouement of the government’s investigati...
headline: Is That It for Financial Crisis Cases?

snippet: Goldman Sachs, which recently announced it was looking to hire a manager for social media, is poised to become an active user of Twitter.
headline: Following Goldman Sachs on Twitter

snippet: The Wall Street firm laid off about 50 people last week, a number of them managing directors, according to people briefed on the matter.
headline: Goldman Sachs Cuts a Little Deeper

snippet: The Manhattan district attorney has charged Sergey Aleynikov, the former Goldman Sachs programmer, with state crimes related to his downloading of computer code from his onetime employer.
headline: Former Goldman Programmer Is Arrested Again

snippet: Two of the most prominent London-based investment bankers of the last two decades have created a new company called Zaoui Capital, according to British regulatory documents.
headline: Zaoui Brothers Establish New Firm

snippet: The comedy Web site “Funny or Die” has weighed in on the brouhaha spawned by a Goldman Sachs executive’s resignation Op-Ed with a slickly produced short sketch starring Kyle MacLachlan.
headline: The Muppets Strike Back at Goldman Sachs

snippet: Using “social impact bonds,” the innovative effort with Rikers Island inmates will be supported by a $7.2 million loan guarantee from the Bloomberg foundation.
headline: Goldman to Invest in City Jail Program, Profiting if Recidivism Falls Sharply

snippet: An executive resigns from his position over an integrity problem too big to ignore.
headline: Why I Am Leaving Goldman Sachs

snippet: Before the program, Johnson Security had no construction-related security business.
headline: One of Goldman Sachs’s 10,000 Small Businesses

snippet: The firm’s decision to name fewer partners comes as dozens of partners have announced plans to leave in a steady exodus over the last year.
headline: Goldman Sachs Expected to Name Fewer Partners

snippet: A Japanese investigation into insider trading has extended onto the trading floors of some of Wall Street’s largest companies, including Goldman Sachs.
headline: Japan Widens Inquiry Into Insider Trading

snippet: An anonymous person using the name “trailmix8″ has posted an account on the finance site Wall Street Oasis of why he left Goldman Sachs after five years at the firm. (This time, no muppets are involved.)
headline: Why I Left Goldman Sachs (Part II)

snippet: A Dutch television program scored a surprisingly detailed 37-minute telephone interview with Lucas van Praag, who is retiring as Goldman’s P.R. chief at the end of March.
headline: Goldman Sachs P.R. Chief’s Accidental Exit Interview

snippet: By stepping into the spotlight even a little, Goldman appears to be embarking on a subtle campaign to repair its reputation. The bank’s message is simple: Goldman cares about its clients and its community.
headline: Once Remote, Goldman Sachs Puts on a Friendly Public Face

snippet: Goldman Sachs has sold $2.5 billion of shares in the Industrial & Commercial Bank of China to the Singaporean sovereign wealth fund Temasek Holdings and other institutional shareholders.
headline: Goldman Sachs Sells Shares in China Bank for $2.5 Billion

snippet: Forstmann Little, the private equity firm that owns 24 Hour Fitness, has hired Goldman Sachs to run an auction that is expected to fetch about $2 billion, say people briefed on the matter.
headline: 24 Hour Fitness Is Said to Be on the Block

snippet: Lloyd Blankfein showed Goldman’s softer side with self-deprecating humor.
headline: With Dimon’s Halo Atilt, Blankfein Looks More Like a Darling

snippet: Deals normally evaporate in the middle of the summer as the temperature rises and bankers decamp for the beach. But the start of this week proved to be an exception to the rule and again revived the concept of a “Merger Monday.”
headline: The Return of Merger Monday, July Edition

snippet: State Street has agreed to pay $550 million for Goldman Sachs’s hedge fund administration unit, a deal that will make State Street the biggest servicer of hedge funds in the world.
headline: State Street to Buy Goldman’s Hedge Fund Administration Unit

snippet: Goldman Sachs reported on Tuesday that its profit fell 12 percent in the second quarter, as the investment bank continued to grapple with a moribund economy.
headline: Goldman’s Earnings Fell 12% in 2nd Quarter

snippet: Anil Kumar, a former top partner at the prestigious consulting firm McKinsey & Company, was a crucial witness for the government in its cases against the hedge fund manager Raj Rajaratnam and a former Goldman Sachs board member, Rajat K. Gupta.
headline: No Jail Time for Cooperating Witness in Galleon Case

snippet: At the Economic Club in Washington, the Goldman Sachs chief discusses regulation, the federal budget — and his interest in a future government post (hint, hint).
headline: In Washington, Blankfein Backs Dodd-Frank

snippet: An appeals court panel has upheld a $20.5 million arbitration award to creditors of the Bayou Group, who had accused Goldman Sachs of helping the hedge fund perpetrate a Ponzi scheme.
headline: Court Upholds Big Award Against Goldman

snippet: When the powerful financial services firm Goldman Sachs moved its headquarters to Battery Park City, it brought along a whole neighborhood, with plenty of amenities, and upended the old one.
headline: It’s a Goldman World

snippet: The remaining public shareholders of CVR are discovering that they are in a strange sort of limbo as a result of the peace treaty the energy company’s former board entered into with Carl C. Icahn.
headline: The Strange Takeover Limbo of CVR

snippet: Investment houses are moving jobs, mostly those of middle-tier staff members, out of the New York area to places like North Carolina, Salt Lake City and Jacksonville, Fla.
headline: Financial Giants Are Moving Jobs Off Wall Street

snippet: Goldman Sachs must continue to pay Mr. Gupta’s bills until the case is completely resolved, a process that could take a couple of years.
headline: Goldman Stuck With a Defense Tab, and Awaiting a Payback

snippet: In a regulatory filing, Goldman disclosed that its 407 partners own 12.7 percent of the the investment, up from 11.4 percent in late October.
headline: Partners’ Stake in Goldman Sachs Rises

snippet: Goldman withdrew as the lead underwriter for the initial public offering of the Russian cellphone operator MegaFon, but the multibillion-dollar offering is hurtling forward nonetheless, highlighting a flawed system.
headline: In Goldman Sachs’s Retreat From I.P.O., a Signal to Investors

snippet: At least one of the three big bank chief executives to survive the financial crisis could be without a job by the end of 2013, the authors contend.
headline: Bank C.E.O.’s on Thinning Ice

snippet: A day after naming 70 executives to its elite partnership, Goldman Sachs has promoted 266 to managing director, the next rung down from partner.
headline: Goldman Sachs Names 266 Managing Directors

snippet: Bausch & Lomb, the eye care products maker, has hired Goldman Sachs to explore a sale of the company in the hopes of fetching more than $10 billion, a person briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.
headline: Bausch & Lomb Said to Hire Goldman to Explore a Sale

snippet: Goldman Sachs has settled C.F.T.C. accusations that it failed to supervise a trader who has been accused of entering fabricated trades that concealed a $8.3 billion trading position.
headline: Goldman to Pay $1.5 Million for Failing to Supervise Trader

snippet: In a surprise decision, a federal appeals court has ruled that Rajat K. Gupta can remain free on bail while he challenges his insider-trading conviction. He was set to start serving a two-year sentence on Jan. 8.
headline: Former Goldman Director Gupta to Stay Free Pending Appeal

snippet: A judge approved a $110 million settlement on Monday between the El Paso Corporation and its shareholders, who sought last year to block the sale of the company’s pipeline business to Kinder Morgan for $21.1 billion.
headline: Judge Approves $110 Million El Paso Corp. Settlement

snippet: Glenn Hadden, who is now head of the global interest rates desk at Morgan Stanley, is under investigation over his trading in Treasury futures while at Goldman Sachs, according to a regulatory filing.
headline: Morgan Stanley Trader Faces Inquiry on Possible Manipulation

snippet: The announcement that Mark Carney will serve as the next head of the Bank of England shows that the “Government Sachs” meme isn’t going anywhere.
headline: Bank of England’s New Leader, a Member of the ‘Government Sachs’ Club

snippet: A career at Goldman made Mark J. Carney, the governor of Canada’s central bank, an atypical figure in his national public service, and his departure for bigger challenges was not unexpected.
headline: New Bank of England Chief Was an Unusual Choice for Canada as Well

snippet: The Onex Corporation of Canada agreed on Monday to buy USI, an insurance brokerage firm, from a Goldman Sachs private equity fund for $2.3 billion.
headline: Onex to Buy USI, an Insurance Broker, for $2.3 Billion

snippet: The acquisition adds to News Corporation’s collection of regional sports networks, and may help fuel its ambitions of creating a national sports network to challenge ESPN.
headline: News Corporation Completes Deal for 49% Stake in YES Network

snippet: Goldman Sachs announced on Wednesday that it had selected 70 executives to become partners, the smallest class size since the company went public in 1999.
headline: Goldman Announces a Slimmed-Down Partnership Class

snippet: Goldman is relying more on technology and reducing expenses as it contends with new regulations and an uncertain market, Goldman’s chief executive, Lloyd C. Blankfein, says.
headline: Under New Rules, Goldman Ponders a Leaner Future

snippet: The sports network, founded in 2002, shows the Yankees and the Brooklyn Nets games.
headline: News Corporation Said to Be Close to Acquiring Stake in YES Network

snippet: The new investors joined Goldman Sachs in a new round of financing that values the streaming music service at $3 billion.
headline: Spotify Attracts Investments From Coca-Cola and Fidelity

snippet: Leucadia is paying 1.2 times tangible book value for Jefferies. Investors aren’t nearly as sanguine about Goldman Sachs or Morgan Stanley.
headline: Why the Jefferies Deal Could Worry Wall Street’s Giants

snippet: Some investors and nonprofits are finding mutual interest through “social impact bonds,” which support social programs with an eye toward a profit.
headline: Getting Back More Than a Warm Feeling

snippet: The book by Greg Smith, a former employee of Goldman Sachs, isn’t scheduled to be released until Monday. But some details are already coming to light.
